Quiz Results

Part 79 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 781-790)

Quiz Attempt #119737

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following Table shows the year-wise data of number of registered cars for four years from 2017 to 2020 in four cities (A, B, C and D). The last column shows the data of population of these cities for the year 2020. Based on the data given in the table answer the questions that follow.CitiesNumbers of Registered carsIn the year 2020 Population of the cities (In Million)2017201820192020A75008000900095000.8B12001350140015000.2C600075008500100000.6D50006000660074000.75Which city has shown maximum percentage growth (%) in registered cars from 2017 to 2020? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.A
  • B.B
  • C.C
  • D.D
Correct Answer: C

Growth in city A = 9500-75007500 × 100 = 26.67%

Growth in city B = 1500-12001200 × 100 = 25%

Growth in city C = 10000-60006000 × 100 = 66.67%

Growth in city D = 7400-50005000 × 100 = 48%

Thus, growth of registered vehicles was maximum in city C.

Question 2
The following Table shows the year-wise data of number of registered cars for four years from 2017 to 2020 in four cities (A, B, C and D). The last column shows the data of population of these cities for the year 2020. Based on the data given in the table answer the questions that follow.CitiesNumbers of Registered carsIn the year 2020 Population of the cities (In Million)2017201820192020A75008000900095000.8B12001350140015000.2C600075008500100000.6D50006000660074000.75In the year 2020, per capita registered cars were maximum in the city: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.D
  • B.C
  • C.B
  • D.A
Correct Answer: C

Per capita registered cars for city A = 9500800000 = 0.012

Per capita registered cars for city B = 1500200000 = 0.0075

Per capita registered cars for city C = 10000600000 = 0.017

Per capita registered cars for city D = 7400750000 = 0.0099

Thus, per capita registered cars were maximum in the city C

Question 3
The following Table shows the year-wise data of number of registered cars for four years from 2017 to 2020 in four cities (A, B, C and D). The last column shows the data of population of these cities for the year 2020. Based on the data given in the table answer the questions that follow.CitiesNumbers of Registered carsIn the year 2020 Population of the cities (In Million)2017201820192020A75008000900095000.8B12001350140015000.2C600075008500100000.6D50006000660074000.75Taking all the cities together, what is the ratio of total number of registered cars in the year 2020 with respect to 2017? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.284:197
  • B.149:154
  • C.142:79
  • D.53:41
Correct Answer: 284:197

Required ratio = 28400 : 19700 = 284:197

Question 4
The following Table shows the year-wise data of number of registered cars for four years from 2017 to 2020 in four cities (A, B, C and D). The last column shows the data of population of these cities for the year 2020. Based on the data given in the table answer the questions that follow.CitiesNumbers of Registered carsIn the year 2020 Population of the cities (In Million)2017201820192020A75008000900095000.8B12001350140015000.2C600075008500100000.6D50006000660074000.75What is the average of percentage growth (%) in registered cars across all the cities from the year 2017 to the year 2018? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.~18%
  • B.~16%
  • C.~14%
  • D.~12%
Correct Answer: ~16%

Required percentage = 22850-1970019700 × 100 ~ 16%

Question 5
The following Table shows the year-wise data of number of registered cars for four years from 2017 to 2020 in four cities (A, B, C and D). The last column shows the data of population of these cities for the year 2020. Based on the data given in the table answer the questions that follow.CitiesNumbers of Registered carsIn the year 2020 Population of the cities (In Million)2017201820192020A75008000900095000.8B12001350140015000.2C600075008500100000.6D50006000660074000.75Based on the average growth percentage (%) of registered cars per year (in successive years during 2017 - 2020) in the city A, what will be the estimated number of registered cars in city A in the year 2021? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.~11225
  • B.~10815
  • C.~10415
  • D.~10283
Correct Answer: ~10283

Average growth from 2017-2020 = 20003

Growth percentage = 200037500 × 100 = 8.89%

 

Vehicles registered in 2021 = 9500 × 1.0889 ~10283

Question 6
Match List -1 with List -II.List – I (Online Teaching Tools)(a) Learning Management System (LMS)(b) Video Conferencing(c) Discussion Forums(d) Online Assessment PlatformsList -II (Advantages for Students)(i) Collaborating with peers, sharing ideas and perspectives(ii) Receiving instant feedback on quizzes and assessments, tracking progress and performance(iii) Accessing course materials and assignments any time, any where(iv) Participating in live online class sessions and discussions from remote locations alsoChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(iii), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)

The correct match is as follows.

 

List – I - List -II

(Online Teaching Tools) - (Advantages for Students)

(a) Learning Management System (LMS) - Accessing course materials and assignments any time, any where

(b) Video Conferencing - Participating in live online class sessions and discussions from remote locations also

(c) Discussion Forums - Collaborating with peers, sharing ideas and perspectives

(d) Online Assessment Platforms - Receiving instant feedback on quizzes and assessments, tracking progress and performance

Question 7
Which of the following are not the examples of a positive teacher - student relationship?(a) A teacher who punishes students for asking questions.(b) A teacher who provides students with positive feedback and constructive criticism.(c) A teacher who fosters open communication and mutual respect.(d) A teacher who humiliates his/her students.(e) A teacher who ignores the needs and concerns of his/her students.Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(b) and (c) only
  • B.(a), (d) and (e) only
  • C.(a), (b), (c) and (d) only
  • D.(b) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (a), (d) and (e) only

The correct answer is (B) i.e., (a), (d) and (e) only.

 

Let us consider each option one by one.

 

Option (a): A teacher who punishes students for asking questions is not an example of a positive teacher-student relationship because it discourages student participation and inquiry.

 

Option (b): A teacher who provides students with positive feedback and constructive criticism fosters a positive teacher-student relationship by encouraging student growth and development.

 

Option (c): A teacher who fosters open communication and mutual respect contributes to a positive teacher-student relationship by creating an environment where students feel valued and supported.

 

Option (d): A teacher who humiliates his/her students is not an example of a positive teacher-student relationship because it damages students' self-esteem and undermines their trust in the teacher.

 

Option (e): A teacher who ignores the needs and concerns of his/her students is not an example of a positive teacher-student relationship because it demonstrates a lack of empathy and support for students' well-being.

Question 8
Match List -IwithList - II.List - I (Online Learning Platforms)(A)Swayam(B)Udemy(C)Skillshare(D) Khan AcademyList - II (Respective Features)(i) Paid courses on creative and entrepreneurial topics(ii) Free courses from Indian universities(iii) Video lectures and interactive exercises for k - 12 students(iv) Paid courses on various topicsChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)

The correct match is as follows.

List - I - List - II

(Online Learning Platforms) - (Respective Features)

(A) Swayam - Free courses from Indian universities

(B) Udemy - Paid courses on various topics

(C) Skillshare - Paid courses on creative and entrepreneurial topics

(D) Khan Academy - Video lectures and interactive exercises for k - 12 students

Question 9
Which of the following is an example of collaborative learning? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.A teacher assigns individually a reading assignment, and students take notes
  • B.A teacher gives lecture on a topic and students take notes individually
  • C.A teacher assigns homework for students to complete independently
  • D.A teacher assigns a group project, and students work together to do research and present their findings
Correct Answer: A teacher assigns a group project, and students work together to do research and present their findings

Collaborative learning involves students working together in groups to achieve a common goal, such as completing a project or solving a problem. Option (D) describes an example of collaborative learning, where students collaborate with each other to research and present their findings as a group project.

Options (A), (B), and (C) all describe activities where students work individually rather than collaboratively.

Question 10
Which of the following is a potential drawback of teacher centered instruction?
  • A.It can be more engaging and interactive for students.
  • B.It can limit opportunities for students' creativity and critical thinking.
  • C.It promotes students' independence and self-direction.
  • D.It is more efficient and saves time.
Correct Answer: It can limit opportunities for students' creativity and critical thinking.

Teacher-centered instruction often involves the teacher leading the learning process, with students passively receiving information. This approach can limit opportunities for students to actively engage in critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity, as they may have fewer opportunities to explore and discover knowledge on their own. In contrast, student-centered instruction tends to foster greater opportunities for students to develop critical thinking skills and creativity through active participation and exploration.

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 11
Identify the correct sequence of steps involved in conducting a literature review for a research study:(a) Locate literature(b) Organize the literature(c) Identify key terms for search(d) Write a literature review(e) Critically evaluate and select the literature relevant to researchChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a), (b), (c), (e), (a)
  • B.(a), (c), (b), (e), (d)
  • C.(c), (a), (e), (b), (d)
  • D.(c), (e), (a), (b), (d)
Correct Answer: (c), (a), (e), (b), (d)

The correct sequence of steps involved in conducting a literature review for a research study is:

(i) Identify key terms for search: Begin by identifying key terms related to the research topic to use in literature searches.

(ii) Locate literature: Use the identified key terms to search for relevant literature in academic databases, libraries, and other sources.

(iii) Critically evaluate and select the literature relevant to research: Evaluate the literature found to determine its relevance and quality for inclusion in the literature review.

(iv) Organize the literature: Organize the selected literature thematically or chronologically to provide structure to the literature review.

(v) Write a literature review: Finally, synthesize and summarize the selected literature to write the literature review section of the research study.

Question 12
The systematic elimination of extraneous variables, other than those you are interested in, can be done in which of the following types of research? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Qualitative research
  • B.Longitudinal research
  • C.Experimental research
  • D.Correlational research
Correct Answer: Experimental research

The systematic elimination of extraneous variables, other than those you are interested in, is typically done in Experimental research.

 

Experimental research involves manipulating variables to observe their effect on other variables, while controlling for extraneous variables that could influence the results. This systematic control allows researchers to establish cause-and-effect relationships between variables.

 

Qualitative research focuses on exploring and understanding phenomena in depth, often in natural settings, and does not typically involve experimental manipulation or control of extraneous variables.

 

Longitudinal research involves studying the same individuals or groups over an extended period of time to observe changes or trends, but it may not necessarily involve experimental manipulation or control of extraneous variables.

Correlational research examines the relationship between two or more variables without manipulating them, and while researchers can statistically control for some extraneous variables, they may not be systematically eliminated as in experimental research.

Question 13
When the researcher's age affects thebehaviourof the participant in a study, it refers to: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Sociological effect
  • B.Biosocial effect
  • C.Psychological effect
  • D.Psychosocial effect
Correct Answer: Biosocial effect

Option B is correct.

The biosocial effect refers to the influence of biological factors, such as age, on social behavior. In the context of research, when the age of the researcher affects the behavior of the participant in a study, it is considered a biosocial effect.

For example, if a participant behaves differently or responds differently to questions based on the age of the researcher conducting the study, it reflects how biological factors (age) can interact with social dynamics to influence behavior.

Question 14
In a negatively skewed distribution, which among the following would be true?(a) Mean > Mode(b) Mean < Median(c) Median < Mode(d) Mode < MeanChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a) and (b) Only
  • B.(b) and (c) Only
  • C.(b) and (d) Only
  • D.(a) and (c) Only
Correct Answer: (b) and (c) Only

Option B is correct.

Mean < Median: The mean is pulled towards the tail of the distribution, which contains lower values. As a result, the mean tends to be smaller than the median, which represents the middle value of the data.

Median < Mode: In a negatively skewed distribution, the tail extends towards the lower values, causing the median to be pulled towards the higher values compared to the mode. However, there can be cases where the mode coincides with the highest frequency point in the distribution, which may or may not be towards the higher end where the tail is located.

Question 15
A researcher obtains the following p values for sample correlation coefficients of different samples. Which of these can be considered significant at 5 % level of significance?(a) 0.5(b) 0.04(c) 0.95(d) 0.002(e) 0.995Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a) and (e) Only
  • B.(b) and (d) Only
  • C.(c) and (e) Only
  • D.(a), (c) and (e) Only
Correct Answer: (b) and (d) Only

Option B is correct.

In hypothesis testing, the p-value represents the probability of obtaining the observed results (or more extreme results) if the null hypothesis is true. A common significance level used in hypothesis testing is 0.05 (5%).

0.04 p-value is less than 0.05. A p-value of 0.04 means there is a 4% chance of obtaining the observed results (or more extreme results) if the null hypothesis is true. Therefore, it can be considered significant at the 5% level of significance.

0.002 p-value is less than 0.05. A p-value of 0.002 means there is a 0.2% chance of obtaining the observed results (or more extreme results) if the null hypothesis is true. Therefore, it can be considered significant at the 5% level of significance.

Question 16
The term 'analog media' was originally derived from: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Folk performances
  • B.Satellite communication
  • C.Internet
  • D.Audio recordings
Correct Answer: Audio recordings

Option D is correct.

The term "analog" refers to a method of representing data or information by continuously varying quantities, such as voltage, sound waves, or light waves. In the context of media, analog refers to media formats that store and transmit information in a continuous, wave-like form, rather than in discrete, digital signals.

Audio recordings were one of the earliest forms of analog media. In analog audio recordings, sound waves are captured and stored directly onto a physical medium, such as magnetic tape or vinyl records, in a continuous waveform. When the recording is played back, the stored sound waves are reproduced, resulting in an accurate representation of the original sound.

Question 17
The automation element of online media has enabled the generation of: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Limited quantity of quality information
  • B.User specific information
  • C.Complex philosophical information
  • D.Non-specific general information
Correct Answer: User specific information

The automation element in online media allows for the collection and analysis of user data, preferences, and behavior. This enables the generation of user-specific information tailored to individual interests, preferences, and demographics.

Question 18
Which of the following are the orders of signification in communication?(a) Denotation(b) Connotation(c) Myth(d) Credibility(e) AttributionChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) Only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) Only
  • C.(c), (d) and (e) Only
  • D.(a), (d) and (e) Only
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c) Only

The orders of signification in communication are as follows.

 

1. First Order of Signification - Denotation

This is like the basic level of understanding. It's the literal meaning of a sign, what you see or hear without any deeper interpretation.

For example, if I say "apple," the denotation is the physical fruit we all recognize as an apple. It's a straightforward, dictionary definition of the word.

 

2. Second Order of Signification - Connotation

This level goes beyond just the literal meaning and involves personal or cultural interpretations. It's about what a sign suggests or implies beyond its surface meaning.

 

Building on the "apple" example, the connotation might include ideas of healthiness, freshness, or even symbols of temptation (like the apple in the story of Adam and Eve).

 

Here, the sign of "apple" is not just about the physical fruit, but it carries additional meanings or associations depending on the context or the person interpreting it.

 

3. Myth - Ideological Interpretation

At this level, connotations are organized into broader ideologies or belief systems. These myths promote the values and interests of dominant groups in society, defending existing power structures.

 

Going back to the "apple" example, the myth might involve ideas about health, nature, or even consumerism. For instance, an advertisement for organic apples might tap into the myth of health and purity, suggesting that buying these apples aligns with a certain lifestyle or set of values.

Essentially, myths shape our perceptions and beliefs, often guiding us to see the world in ways that benefit those in power.

 

Thus, the process of signification starts with the basic, literal meaning (denotation) of a sign, but it doesn't stop there. It moves into deeper, more nuanced interpretations (connotation) that are influenced by personal and cultural factors. Finally, these interpretations are organized into broader ideologies or myths that shape our understanding of the world and our place in it.

 

Based on the above discussion, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 19
In the context of communication, politicalsocialisationis linked to social learning in terms of how?(a) Power is attained.(b) Certain sections of society should be left out of the mainstream(c) Social systems are ignored.(d) Power is used and misused.(e) Political and economic decisions are made.Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) Only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) Only
  • C.(a), (d) and (e) Only
  • D.(b), (d) and (e) Only
Correct Answer: (a), (d) and (e) Only

In the context of communication, political socialisation is linked to social learning in terms of following:

(i) how power is attained: Political socialization and social learning can influence how individuals perceive and pursue power in political contexts.

(ii) how power is used and misused: Understanding political processes and norms through social learning can affect how individuals perceive and use power, including its misuse.

(iii) how political and economic decisions are made: Political socialization and social learning shape individuals' understanding of how political and economic decisions are made, influencing their attitudes and behaviors in these domains.

Question 20
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Not every medium has its own grammar.Statement (II):Each media grammar has evolved over a period of time and continues to change.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Statement I is incorrect. While the medium may affect how messages are received, the users’/audiences’ own background/experience may also affect the interpretation of messages. An important first step in becoming media and information literate is to understand how information, ideas and meaning are communicated through and by various media and other information providers, such as libraries, archives, museums and the Internet. Each medium has its own ‘language’ or ‘grammar’ that works to convey meaning in a unique way. ‘Language’ in this sense means the technical and symbolic ingredients or codes and conventions that media and information professionals may select and use in an effort to communicate ideas, information and knowledge. Technical codes include sound, camera angles, types of shots and lighting. They may include, for example, ominous music to communicate danger in a feature film, or high-angle camera shots to create a feeling of power in a photograph. Symbolic codes include the language, dress or actions of characters, or iconic symbols that are easily understood. For example, a red rose may be used symbolically to convey romance, or a clenched fist may be used to communicate anger. Media languages can also include the repeated use of particular words, phrases and images, also known as verbal or visual language.

Statement II is correct because the grammar of each medium has evolved over time. For instance, the grammar of film or television has evolved since their inception, with changes in techniques, styles, and conventions influenced by technological advancements and cultural shifts.

Question 21
What number would replace question mark (?) in the series given below?1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21, ?, 36, . (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.32
  • B.28
  • C.29
  • D.30
Correct Answer: 28

Next number = 21 + 7 = 28

Question 22
The ratio of water and milk in a 27litremixture is 5:4. Find the quantity of water to be added to the mixture in order to make the ratio of water and milk as 3:1. (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.12litres
  • B.15litres
  • C.21litres
  • D.36litres
Correct Answer: 21litres

Let x litre water will be added.

Then, 15+x12 = 31

or x = 21 litres

Question 23
The difference between the compound interest and simple interest on a principal amount for 2 years at 10% per annum isRs. 5431. Find the principal amount. (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Rs. 54310
  • B.Rs. 108620
  • C.Rs. 453100
  • D.Rs. 543100
Correct Answer: Rs. 543100

Let P be the principal.

Then, P(1.1)2 – P - P×10×2100 = 5431

or P = 543100

Question 24
Two friends A and B live 140 km apart. They both drive in a straight line towards each other to meet. If A drives at 80 km/h and B drives at 40 km/hr, then how many kilometers apart will they be exactly 45 minutes before they meet? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.70 km
  • B.90 km
  • C.100 km
  • D.80 km
Correct Answer: 90 km

A and B will meet at time = 140120 = 70 mins

Before 45 minutes of there meet, they travelled for 25 minutes.

Distance between them at that time = 140 – 120 × 2560 = 90 km

Question 25
In a certain coded language, 'RAM' is coded as 32 and ‘SITA' is coded as 49. How `SHYAM’ will be coded in that language? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.73
  • B.49
  • C.66
  • D.32
Correct Answer: 66

R + A + M = 18 + 1 + 13 = 32

S + I + T + A = 19 + 9 + 20 + 1 = 49

Similarly,

S + H + Y + A + M = 19 + 8 + 25 + 1 + 13 = 66

Question 26
Analogy roughly corresponds to : (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Anumiti
  • B.Upamiti
  • C.Agama
  • D.Pratyaksha
Correct Answer: Upamiti

Option B is correct.

An analogy is a comparison between two things, typically for the purpose of explanation or clarification. In Indian philosophical traditions such as Nyaya (Logic) and Mimamsa (Interpretation), analogy plays a significant role in reasoning and argumentation. Upamiti corresponds most closely to analogy. Upamiti means 'resemblance' or 'similitude' and is often used to establish a comparison between two things to illustrate a point or to convey a concept.

Question 27
In order to know if the argument is deductive or inductive, out of the four given tests which one applies to the followingexample?"Alan is a father. Therefore, Alan is a male". (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.The Indicator word test
  • B.The Strict necessity test
  • C.The Common pattern test
  • D.The Principle of charity test
Correct Answer: The Strict necessity test

To distinguish between deductive and inductive arguments, we can use the following tests:

 

Indicator Word Test: Look for words like "certainly" for deductive arguments and "probably" for inductive arguments.

 

Strict Necessity Test: If the conclusion logically follows from the premises, it's deductive; if not, it's likely inductive.

 

Common Pattern Test: If the argument follows a pattern typical of deductive reasoning, it's deductive. For example, "If A, then B. A. Therefore, B."

 

Principle of Charity Test: Always give the arguer the benefit of the doubt and interpret their argument in the strongest way possible.

Question 28
Pick a correct observation from the following argument:"All dogs are catsAll cats are whalesTherefore, all whales are dogs" (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.It is valid argument and contains true premise and true conclusion
  • B.It is invalid argument and contains false premise and true conclusion
  • C.It is invalid argument and contains false premise and false conclusion
  • D.It is invalid argument and contains true premise and false conclusion
Correct Answer: It is invalid argument and contains false premise and false conclusion

Option C is the correct answer. It is invalid argument and contains false premise and false conclusion.

Question 29
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Arguments from analogy are generally deductive, weak or strong.Statement (II):Arguments from analogy are generally inductive and neither valid nor invalid.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.

Question 30
In the light of syllogistic argument which of the following is/are incorrect?(a) The predicate term of the conclusion is the major term.(b) The subject term of the conclusion is the minor term.(c) The middle term must occur only once in the premise.(d) The middle term must be distributed at least once in the conclusion.Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(b) Only
  • B.(b) and (d) Only
  • C.(c) Only
  • D.(c) and (d) Only
Correct Answer: (c) and (d) Only

The incorrect statements are:

(c) The middle term must occur only once in the premise.

In a standard categorical syllogism, the middle term must occur exactly twice, once in each premise.

(d) The middle term must be distributed at least once in the conclusion.

The middle term must be distributed at least once in the premises and it necessarily need not be distributed in conclusion.

Question 31
Anil has an MP3 file stored on his computer. Which type of data is stored in an MP3 file? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Video
  • B.Sound
  • C.Image
  • D.Text
Correct Answer: Sound

Option B is correct.

An MP3 (MPEG-1 Audio Layer III) file is a type of digital audio file format used for storing and playing sound recordings. MP3 files compress audio data using a lossy compression algorithm, which reduces the file size while preserving most of the original audio quality. This makes MP3 files suitable for storing music, speech, or any other type of audio content.

Question 32
Identify the correct sequence of the following technologies A-D used in first generation to fourth generation of computers.(a) Integrated circuits(b) Microprocessors(c) Transistors(d) Vacuum TubesChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(d), (c), (b), (a)
  • B.(d), (c), (a), (b)
  • C.(c), (d), (a), (b)
  • D.(b), (a), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (d), (c), (a), (b)

Option B is correct.

The first generation of computers, which emerged in the late 1940s and 1950s, used vacuum tube technology for electronic circuitry. Vacuum tubes were large, fragile, and generated a significant amount of heat, limiting the size and reliability of early computers.

The second generation of computers, developed in the late 1950s and 1960s, replaced vacuum tubes with transistor technology. Transistors were smaller, more reliable, and consumed less power than vacuum tubes, enabling the development of smaller and more efficient computers.

The third generation of computers, introduced in the 1960s and 1970s, utilized integrated circuit (IC) technology. Integrated circuits combined multiple transistors, resistors, and other components onto a single semiconductor chip, dramatically reducing the size and cost of electronic devices.

The fourth generation of computers, which began in the 1970s, saw the advent of microprocessor technology. Microprocessors are complete central processing units (CPUs) contained on a single chip, integrating the functions of the CPU onto a single semiconductor component. This innovation led to the development of personal computers (PCs) and other highly compact and powerful computing devices.

Question 33
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):(1011101)2=(5D)16Statement (II):(C2)16=(11000010)2In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

(5D)16 = 13 × 160 + 5 × 161 = 93

(1011101)2 = 1 × 20 + 0 × 21 + 1 × 22 + 1 × 23 + 1 × 24 + 0 × 25 + 1 × 26

= 64 + 16 + 8 + 4 + 1 = 93

 

(C2)16 = 2 × 160 + 12 × 161 = 194

(11000010)2 = 0 × 20 + 1 × 21 + 0 × 22 + 0 × 23 + 0 × 24 + 0 × 25 + 1 × 26 + 1 × 27

= 128 + 64 + 2

= 194

 

Thus, both the statements are correct.

Question 34
Which of the following computer memory types are volatile?(a) CMOS memory(b) Cache memory(c) Flash memory(d) Hard disk(e) RAMChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a), (b) and (e) Only
  • B.(a), (c) and (d) Only
  • C.(b), (c) and (e) Only
  • D.(b) and (e) Only
Correct Answer: (b) and (e) Only

Option D is correct.

Volatile memory is a type of computer memory that requires power to maintain stored data. When the power is turned off, volatile memory loses its stored information. The following memory types are volatile:

Cache memory: Cache memory is a type of high-speed volatile memory that temporarily stores frequently accessed data and instructions for quick access by the CPU. It is faster than main memory (RAM) but has a smaller capacity.

RAM (Random Access Memory): RAM is the primary volatile memory used by computers to store data and program instructions that are actively being used or processed by the CPU. It allows for quick read and write operations but loses its contents when the power is turned off.

Question 35
Match List - IwithList - II.List - I (Storage Media)(A) Hard Disk Drive (HDD)(B) USB Flash Memory(C)Bluray DiscList - II (Type of storage)(I) Optical(II) Magnetic(III) Solid stateChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a)-(II), (b)-(III), (c)-(I)
  • B.(a)-(II), (b)-(I), (c)-(III)
  • C.(a)-(III), (b)-(II), (c)-(I)
  • D.(a)-(I), (b)-(III), (c)-(II)
Correct Answer: (a)-(II), (b)-(III), (c)-(I)

Option A is correct.

HDDs use magnetic storage technology to store and retrieve digital information. Data is written and read using magnetic heads that move across spinning magnetic disks. Therefore, HDDs are classified as magnetic storage media.

USB flash drives use solid-state storage technology, which means they store data using integrated circuits (ICs) without any moving parts. Solid-state storage is a type of non-volatile memory, making USB flash drives classified as solid-state storage media.

Blu-ray discs utilize optical storage technology, where data is stored and retrieved using lasers to read and write data on a reflective surface. Optical storage relies on the reflection of light, making Blu-ray discs classified as optical storage media.

Question 36
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as Assertion ‘A’ and the other is labelled as Reason ‘R’.Assertion ‘A’:In the less developed countries of the world indoor exposure to hazardous air pollutants is much more severe.Reason ‘R’:Traditional methods of cooking often involve fuels such as coal, wood, animal, dung, kerosene etc.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct and ‘R’ is the correct explanation of ‘A’
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct but ‘R’ is not the correct explanation of ‘A’
  • C.‘A’ is correct but ‘R’ is not correct
  • D.‘A’ is not correct but ‘R’ is correct
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct and ‘R’ is the correct explanation of ‘A’

Option A is correct.

Assertion “A” is correct. In less developed countries, indoor exposure to hazardous air pollutants is much more severe. This is due to several factors such as poor ventilation in housing, the widespread use of traditional cooking methods, and reliance on solid fuels such as coal, wood, animal dung, and kerosene for cooking and heating purposes. These factors contribute to high levels of indoor air pollution, leading to significant health risks for the population.

Reason “R” is correct and directly supports Assertion 'A'. These traditional cooking methods emit various pollutants such as particulate matter, carbon monoxide, volatile organic compounds, and other harmful substances into the indoor air, contributing to indoor air pollution.

Question 37
Addressing nation on independence day 2019, Prime Minister SriNarendraModiset a goal of tap water to every rural house hold by the year: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.2024
  • B.2025
  • C.2027
  • D.2030
Correct Answer: 2024

Option A is correct.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the goal of providing tap water to every rural household in India by 2024 during his address to the nation on Independence Day in 2019. This initiative is known as the Jal Jeevan Mission and aims to ensure access to safe and adequate drinking water to all rural households across the country. It's part of the government's broader efforts to improve water availability, quality, and accessibility, particularly in rural areas where access to clean drinking water can be challenging.

Question 38
Given below are two statements:Statement I:A nuclear breeder reactor produces more fissile material than it consumes.Statement II:Present share of nuclear energy in the energy mix of the country is more than that of renewable energy.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Option C is correct.

Statement I is correct. A nuclear breeder reactor is designed to produce more fissile material (such as plutonium-239) than it consumes. This is achieved through the process of breeding, where fertile material (such as uranium-238) absorbs neutrons and transforms into fissile material.

Statement II is incorrect. The share of nuclear energy in the energy mix of the country is greater than the share of renewable energy. However, in many countries, including some with significant nuclear energy capacities, the share of renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, hydro, and biomass has been increasing rapidly in recent years. Therefore, it is unlikely that the share of nuclear energy would surpass that of renewable energy in the current energy mix of a country.

Question 39
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as Assertion ‘A’ and the other is labelled as Reason ‘R’.Assertion ‘A’:Coral reefs are threatened because of release of sewage in ocean waters near them.Reason ‘R’:Release of sewage in oceans tends to reduce the clarity of ocean water.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct and ‘R’ is the correct explanation of ‘A’
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct but ‘R’ is not the correct explanation of ‘A’
  • C.‘A’ is correct but ‘R’ is not correct
  • D.‘A’ is not correct but ‘R’ is correct
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct and ‘R’ is the correct explanation of ‘A’

Option A is correct.

Assertion “A” is correct. Sewage released into ocean waters near coral reefs can pose a significant threat to their health and survival. Sewage often contains pollutants such as nutrients (e.g., nitrogen and phosphorus), chemicals, and pathogens. These pollutants can lead to water quality degradation, increased algal growth, and disease outbreaks among coral reefs, ultimately causing their decline.

Reason “R” is also correct. When sewage is released into ocean waters, it introduces suspended solids, organic matter, and other contaminants, which can reduce the clarity or transparency of the water. This reduction in water clarity can have various negative impacts on marine ecosystems, including coral reefs, by reducing light penetration necessary for photosynthesis and disrupting ecological processes.

Reason “R” provides valid explanation of Assertion “A” as sewage release can threaten coral reefs.

Question 40
Convention on Biodiversity (CBD) was opened for signature during : (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Earth Summit
  • B.Montreal Protocol
  • C.Kyoto protocol
  • D.Stockholm Convention
Correct Answer: Earth Summit

Option A is correct.

The Earth Summit, officially known as the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED), was held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 1992. It was during this summit that the CBD was opened for signature, reflecting global efforts to address biodiversity conservation and sustainable use.

Question 41
Which of the following are not the characteristics of conventional learning?(a) Emphasis onself directedlearning and independent study(b) Students learn through listening and observation(c) No fixed curriculum(d) Learner oriented(e) Require regular attendanceChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(b) and (e) Only
  • B.(a) and (e) Only
  • C.(a), (c) and (d) Only
  • D.(b) and (c) Only
Correct Answer: (a), (c) and (d) Only

Let us consider each option one by one.

 

(a) Emphasis on self-directed learning and independent study: This is not a characteristic of conventional learning. Conventional learning typically involves structured instruction and guidance from teachers or curriculum materials.

 

(c) No fixed curriculum: Conventional learning usually follows a fixed curriculum or syllabus, while unconventional or alternative forms of education may offer more flexibility in curriculum design.

 

(d) Learner-oriented: Conventional learning tends to be more teacher-oriented, with instructors leading and directing the learning process, rather than being learner-oriented where the focus is on individual student needs and preferences.

 

Options (b) and (e) are characteristics of conventional learning:

 

(b) Students learn through listening and observation: In conventional learning environments like classrooms, students often learn through listening to lectures and observing demonstrations or presentations.

 

(e) Require regular attendance: Conventional learning typically involves regular attendance in classes or sessions scheduled according to a set timetable.

 

Thus, option C is correct.

Question 42
Arrange the following universities in the chronological order of their establishment.(a) Banaras Hindu University(b) Jawaharlal Nehru University(c) University of Allahabad(d) University of DelhiChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(c), (a), (d) (b)
  • B.(a), (c), (d), (b)
  • C.(a), (d), (c), (b)
  • D.(a), (c), (b), (d)
Correct Answer: (c), (a), (d) (b)

The chronological order of establishment of universities is as follows.

University of Allahabad – 1887

Banaras Hindu University – 1916

University of Delhi - 1922

Jawaharlal Nehru University – 1969

Hence, option (A) is correct.

Question 43
Given below are two statements in the context of NEP 2020:Statement (I):It is envisaged that all higher education institutions shall aim to become autonomous and have an empowered Board of Governors (BoG).Statement (II):Institutional Development plan shall be the sole responsibility of the members of (BoG).In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Statement I correct.

According to NEP 2020, through a suitable system of graded accreditation and graded autonomy, and in a phased manner over a period of 15 years, all HEIs in India will aim to become independent self-governing institutions pursuing innovation and excellence. Measures will be taken at all HEIs to ensure leadership of the highest quality and promote an institutional culture of excellence. Upon receiving the appropriate graded accreditations that deem the institution ready for such a move, a Board of Governors (BoG) shall be established consisting of a group of highly qualified, competent, and dedicated individuals having proven capabilities and a strong sense of commitment to the institution. The BoG of an institution will be empowered to govern the institution free of any external interference, make all appointments including that of head of the institution, and take all decisions regarding governance.

 

Statement II is incorrect.

According to NEP 2020, each institution will make a strategic Institutional Development Plan (IDP) on the basis of which institutions will develop initiatives, assess their own progress, and reach the goals set therein, which could then become the basis for further public funding. The IDP shall be prepared with the joint participation of Board members, institutional leaders, faculty, students, and staff.

Question 44
Which among the following is not a value as propounded by the Indian traditional concept ofPurushartha: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Dharma
  • B.Artha
  • C.Bhakti
  • D.Moksha
Correct Answer: Bhakti

The Indian traditional concept of Purushartha consists of four main values or goals known as the "four Purusharthas." These are:

1. Dharma: Duty, righteousness, moral and ethical principles.

2. Artha: Material prosperity, wealth, and success.

3. Kama: Pleasure, desire, and enjoyment.

4. Moksha: Liberation, spiritual enlightenment, and freedom from the cycle of birth and death.

 

Bhakti, on the other hand, is a concept associated with devotion or religious worship, particularly in Hinduism. While bhakti is an important aspect of Hindu spirituality, it is not one of the traditional Purusharthas.

Question 45
Which commission/committee recommended that 'the ordinary amenities and decencies of life should be provided for women in colleges ordinarily planned for men and that there should be no curtailment of opportunities for women? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.DurgabaiDeshmukhCommittee (1959)
  • B.Kothari Commission (1964 - 66)
  • C.Bhaktavatsalamcommittee (1963)
  • D.RadhakrishnanCommission (1948)
Correct Answer: RadhakrishnanCommission (1948)

Radhakrishnan Commission or University Education Commission, (1948-49) noted the importance of Women’s education and stated that, “There cannot be an educated people without educated women. If general education had to be limited to men or to women, that opportunity should be given to women, for then it would most surely be passed on to the next generation.”

 

The key recommendations of the Commission were as follows.

1) Ordinary amenities and decencies of life should be provided for women in colleges originally planned for men, but to which women are being admitted in increasing numbers.

2) There should be no curtailment in educational opportunities for women, but rather a great increase;

3) There should be intelligent educational guidance, by qualified men and women to help women to get a clearer view of their real educational interest, to the end that they shall not try to imitate men but shall desire as good education as men get. Women’s and men’s education should have many elements in common, but should not in general be identical in all respects, as is usually the case today;

4) Women students in general should be helped to see their normal places in a normal society, both as citizens and as women and to prepare for it, and college programmes should be so designed that it will be possible for them to do so;

5) Through educational counsel and by example the prevailing prejudices against study of home economics and home management should be overcome;

6) Standards of courtesy and social responsibility should be emphasised on the part of men in mixed colleges.

7) Where new colleges are established to serve both men and women students, they should be truly co-educational institutions, with as much thought and consideration given to the life need of women as to those of men.

Except as such colleges come into existence there are no valid criteria for comparing segregated education with co-education.

8) Women teachers should be paid the same salaries as men teachers for equal work.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Fascist economics places itself in between free market capitalism and communism. It criticizes the former for prioritizing profits over collective goals, for promoting speculation, financial wizardry that is similar to usury. It agreed to some degree with communists that the capitalist class exploited thelabourforce and was insensitive to poor working conditions but disagreed on the solution. While communists prescribed a proletariat takeover of the means of production followed by a dictatorship of the proletariat as the panacea to the crisis of capitalism, fascism would choose instead to resolve class conflicts betweenlabourand capital through state arbitration and corporate control over the economy. Corporatism is the theory and practice of organizing society into 'corporations' subordinate to the state. These corporations would serve as organs of political consultations and take responsibility, to a large extent, for persons and activities within their jurisdiction. It differed from communism since it rejected classless egalitarianism. It can be described as a modern analogue of feudal guild societies. Thus, corporatism served to retain the social order and hierarchies of feudalism while infusing it with modern industrial methods more conducive for military competition and arms races.Another aspect that fascism had in common with feudal economics is its emphasis on usury laws. Both considered charging interest on loans as being exploitative and immoral. This reinforced a certain worldview which saw tangible sectors such as agriculture and industry as value creating and finance as a sector that rested on tricks and manipulation.Fascist economics agreed with communists on the following:(a) Capitalists are sensitive to the poor working conditions of thelabourforce.(b) Capitalists promote speculation.(c) Capitalists prioritize profits over collective goals.(d) Capitalists indulge in financial wizardly.Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a), (c) and (d) Only
  • B.(b) and (c) Only
  • C.(b), (c) and (d) Only
  • D.(a), (b) and (c) Only
Correct Answer: (b), (c) and (d) Only

The correct answer is option (C), i.e., (b), (c), and (d) only.

Statement (b) Capitalists promote speculation: This is mentioned in the passage where fascist economics criticizes capitalism for promoting speculation, financial wizardry, and usury.

Statement (c) Capitalists prioritize profits over collective goals: This is stated in the passage, which criticizes capitalism for prioritizing profits over collective goals.

Statement (d) Capitalists indulge in financial wizardry: This is mentioned in the passage, which criticizes capitalism for promoting financial wizardry similar to usury.

Statement (a) is incorrect because the passage does not state that capitalists are sensitive to the poor working conditions of the labour force. Instead, it mentions that fascism agrees to some extent with communists that the capitalist class exploited the labour force and was insensitive to poor working conditions, but it disagrees on the solution.

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Fascist economics places itself in between free market capitalism and communism. It criticizes the former for prioritizing profits over collective goals, for promoting speculation, financial wizardry that is similar to usury. It agreed to some degree with communists that the capitalist class exploited thelabourforce and was insensitive to poor working conditions but disagreed on the solution. While communists prescribed a proletariat takeover of the means of production followed by a dictatorship of the proletariat as the panacea to the crisis of capitalism, fascism would choose instead to resolve class conflicts betweenlabourand capital through state arbitration and corporate control over the economy. Corporatism is the theory and practice of organizing society into 'corporations' subordinate to the state. These corporations would serve as organs of political consultations and take responsibility, to a large extent, for persons and activities within their jurisdiction. It differed from communism since it rejected classless egalitarianism. It can be described as a modern analogue of feudal guild societies. Thus, corporatism served to retain the social order and hierarchies of feudalism while infusing it with modern industrial methods more conducive for military competition and arms races.Another aspect that fascism had in common with feudal economics is its emphasis on usury laws. Both considered charging interest on loans as being exploitative and immoral. This reinforced a certain worldview which saw tangible sectors such as agriculture and industry as value creating and finance as a sector that rested on tricks and manipulation.Given below are two statements:Statement I:The communist solution to capitalism was thetake overof the means of production by the proletariat.Statement II:The fascist solution to capitalism was corporatism.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Statement I: The communist solution to capitalism was the takeover of the means of production by the proletariat. This statement accurately reflects the communist solution as described in the passage.

Statement II: The fascist solution to capitalism was corporatism. This statement is accurate as the passage mentions that fascism would choose instead to resolve class conflicts between labour and capital through state arbitration and corporate control over the economy. Corporatism is the theory and practice of organizing society into 'corporations' subordinate to the state.

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Fascist economics places itself in between free market capitalism and communism. It criticizes the former for prioritizing profits over collective goals, for promoting speculation, financial wizardry that is similar to usury. It agreed to some degree with communists that the capitalist class exploited thelabourforce and was insensitive to poor working conditions but disagreed on the solution. While communists prescribed a proletariat takeover of the means of production followed by a dictatorship of the proletariat as the panacea to the crisis of capitalism, fascism would choose instead to resolve class conflicts betweenlabourand capital through state arbitration and corporate control over the economy. Corporatism is the theory and practice of organizing society into 'corporations' subordinate to the state. These corporations would serve as organs of political consultations and take responsibility, to a large extent, for persons and activities within their jurisdiction. It differed from communism since it rejected classless egalitarianism. It can be described as a modern analogue of feudal guild societies. Thus, corporatism served to retain the social order and hierarchies of feudalism while infusing it with modern industrial methods more conducive for military competition and arms races.Another aspect that fascism had in common with feudal economics is its emphasis on usury laws. Both considered charging interest on loans as being exploitative and immoral. This reinforced a certain worldview which saw tangible sectors such as agriculture and industry as value creating and finance as a sector that rested on tricks and manipulation.Classless egalitarianism policy was followed by: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Feudalism
  • B.Capitalism
  • C.Communism
  • D.Fascism
Correct Answer: Communism

Classless egalitarianism policy was followed by Communism.

The passage mentions that corporatism, as practiced in fascist economics, rejected classless egalitarianism, which implies that communism, characterized by classless egalitarianism, is the opposite.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Fascist economics places itself in between free market capitalism and communism. It criticizes the former for prioritizing profits over collective goals, for promoting speculation, financial wizardry that is similar to usury. It agreed to some degree with communists that the capitalist class exploited thelabourforce and was insensitive to poor working conditions but disagreed on the solution. While communists prescribed a proletariat takeover of the means of production followed by a dictatorship of the proletariat as the panacea to the crisis of capitalism, fascism would choose instead to resolve class conflicts betweenlabourand capital through state arbitration and corporate control over the economy. Corporatism is the theory and practice of organizing society into 'corporations' subordinate to the state. These corporations would serve as organs of political consultations and take responsibility, to a large extent, for persons and activities within their jurisdiction. It differed from communism since it rejected classless egalitarianism. It can be described as a modern analogue of feudal guild societies. Thus, corporatism served to retain the social order and hierarchies of feudalism while infusing it with modern industrial methods more conducive for military competition and arms races.Another aspect that fascism had in common with feudal economics is its emphasis on usury laws. Both considered charging interest on loans as being exploitative and immoral. This reinforced a certain worldview which saw tangible sectors such as agriculture and industry as value creating and finance as a sector that rested on tricks and manipulation.Fascist economics is based on: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Communism
  • B.Capitalism
  • C.A mix of communism and capitalism
  • D.Feudalism
Correct Answer: A mix of communism and capitalism

Fascist economics is positioned between free-market capitalism and communism, incorporating elements of both systems while also introducing its own unique features, such as corporatism and state control over the economy.

Question 50
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Fascist economics places itself in between free market capitalism and communism. It criticizes the former for prioritizing profits over collective goals, for promoting speculation, financial wizardry that is similar to usury. It agreed to some degree with communists that the capitalist class exploited thelabourforce and was insensitive to poor working conditions but disagreed on the solution. While communists prescribed a proletariat takeover of the means of production followed by a dictatorship of the proletariat as the panacea to the crisis of capitalism, fascism would choose instead to resolve class conflicts betweenlabourand capital through state arbitration and corporate control over the economy. Corporatism is the theory and practice of organizing society into 'corporations' subordinate to the state. These corporations would serve as organs of political consultations and take responsibility, to a large extent, for persons and activities within their jurisdiction. It differed from communism since it rejected classless egalitarianism. It can be described as a modern analogue of feudal guild societies. Thus, corporatism served to retain the social order and hierarchies of feudalism while infusing it with modern industrial methods more conducive for military competition and arms races.Another aspect that fascism had in common with feudal economics is its emphasis on usury laws. Both considered charging interest on loans as being exploitative and immoral. This reinforced a certain worldview which saw tangible sectors such as agriculture and industry as value creating and finance as a sector that rested on tricks and manipulation.Fascism:(a) Considered charging interest as immoral(b) Valued agriculture and Industry(c) Rejected hierarchies of feudalism(d) Believed in corporatismChoose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.(a) and (d) Only
  • B.(a), (b) and (c) Only
  • C.(a), (c) and (d) Only
  • D.(a), (b) and (d) Only
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (d) Only

Fascism considered charging interest as immoral, valued agriculture and industry, and believed in corporatism. However, it did not necessarily reject the hierarchies of feudalism, as corporatism served to retain some aspects of feudal social order and hierarchies. Thus option (D) is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119738

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
Read the following passage and answer the question that follows:The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of teachers in six different subjects - Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Zoology, Education and Hindi, in a University in the year 2022, along with the ratio of male to female teachers in each subject. Total number of teachers in the subject of Physics is 448. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Subject-wise Distribution of TeachersSubjectPercentage (%)Distribution of TeachersRatio of TeachersMales: FemalesPhysics14%9:5Chemistry13%1:7Mathematics21%3:4Zoology22%7:9Education18%5:3Hindi12%1:3What is the total number of teachers (both male and female) and the total number of male teachers in the university, respectively?
  • A.3000 and 1592
  • B.3200 and 1392
  • C.3200 and 1808
  • D.3000 and 1608
Correct Answer: 3200 and 1392

Since teachers in physics = 448

Total teachers = 4480.14 = 3200

Question 2
Read the following passage and answer the question that follows:The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of teachers in six different subjects - Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Zoology, Education and Hindi, in a University in the year 2022, along with the ratio of male to female teachers in each subject. Question 3
Read the following passage and answer the question that follows:The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of teachers in six different subjects - Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Zoology, Education and Hindi, in a University in the year 2022, along with the ratio of male to female teachers in each subject. Total number of teachers in the subject of Physics is 448. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Subject-wise Distribution of TeachersSubjectPercentage (%)Distribution of TeachersRatio of TeachersMales: FemalesPhysics14%9:5Chemistry13%1:7Mathematics21%3:4Zoology22%7:9Education18%5:3Hindi12%1:3Number of teachers (both male and female) in Hindi is approximately ________ % less than the total number of female teachers in Mathematics and Chemistry together.
  • A.43.59
  • B.51.44
  • C.42.81
  • D.48.66
Correct Answer: 48.66

Since teachers in physics = 448

Total teachers = 4480.14 = 3200

Question 4
Read the following passage and answer the question that follows:The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of teachers in six different subjects - Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Zoology, Education and Hindi, in a University in the year 2022, along with the ratio of male to female teachers in each subject. Total number of teachers in the subject of Physics is 448. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Subject-wise Distribution of TeachersSubjectPercentage (%)Distribution of TeachersRatio of TeachersMales: FemalesPhysics14%9:5Chemistry13%1:7Mathematics21%3:4Zoology22%7:9Education18%5:3Hindi12%1:3What is the ratio between the total number of teachers (both male and female) in Zoology and the total number of male teachers in Chemistry and Education together?
  • A.176:103
  • B.51:41
  • C.101:83
  • D.71:59
Correct Answer: 176:103

Since teachers in physics = 448

Question 5
Read the following passage and answer the question that follows:The following table shows the percentage (%) distribution of teachers in six different subjects - Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Zoology, Education and Hindi, in a University in the year 2022, along with the ratio of male to female teachers in each subject. Total number of teachers in the subject of Physics is 448. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Subject-wise Distribution of TeachersSubjectPercentage (%)Distribution of TeachersRatio of TeachersMales: FemalesPhysics14%9:5Chemistry13%1:7Mathematics21%3:4Zoology22%7:9Education18%5:3Hindi12%1:3What is the difference between the total number of female teachers and male teachers in the University?
  • A.408
  • B.412
  • C.416
  • D.420
Correct Answer: 416

Since teachers in physics = 448

Total teachers = 4480.14 = 3200
