Environmental education is crucial for various reasons related to environmental conservation and sustainability. The options (a), (b), and (c) directly align with the objectives of environmental education:

(a) Conservation of natural resources: Environmental education helps individuals understand the importance of conserving natural resources and promotes sustainable practices.

(b) Knowledge of causes of pollution: Understanding the causes of pollution is essential for identifying and addressing environmental issues effectively.

(c) Knowledge of measures to prevent pollution: Environmental education equips individuals with the knowledge and skills needed to implement measures to prevent pollution and mitigate its impacts.

Question 46
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:Saving energy means saving money. Homeowners and renters know this basic fact, but they often don't know what kinds of adjustments they can make in their homes and apartments that will result in savings.For those willing to spend some time and money to reap long-term energy savings, an energy audit is the way to go. An energy auditor will come into your home and assess its energy efficiency. The auditor will pinpoint areas of your home that use the most energy and offer solutions to lower your energy use and costs. Trained energy auditors know what to look for and can locate a variety of flaws that may be resulting in energy inefficiency, including inadequate insulation, construction flaws, and uneven heat distribution.There are quicker and less costly measures that can be taken as well. One way to save money is to replace incandescent lights with fluorescent lights. This can result in a savings of more than 50% on your monthly lighting costs. When it's time to replace old appliances, it’s wise to spend a bit more for an energy-efficient model, and be sure that you are taking advantage of energy-saving settings already on your current refrigerator, dishwasher, washing machine, or dryer.Windows provide another opportunity to cut your energy costs. Caulk old windows that might be leaky to prevent drafts, and choose double-paned windows if you're building an addition or replacing old windows.Most areas of your home or apartment offer opportunities to save energy and money. The results are significant and are well worth the effort.The passage indicates that old appliances: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.Consume more energy
  • B.Consume less energy
  • C.Work well
  • D.Have long life
Correct Answer: Consume more energy

The passage suggests that when it's time to replace old appliances, it's wise to spend a bit more on an energy-efficient model. This implies that old appliances, which are not energy-efficient, consume more energy compared to newer, energy-efficient models. Therefore, option (A) is correct.

Question 47
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:Saving energy means saving money. Homeowners and renters know this basic fact, but they often don't know what kinds of adjustments they can make in their homes and apartments that will result in savings.For those willing to spend some time and money to reap long-term energy savings, an energy audit is the way to go. An energy auditor will come into your home and assess its energy efficiency. The auditor will pinpoint areas of your home that use the most energy and offer solutions to lower your energy use and costs. Trained energy auditors know what to look for and can locate a variety of flaws that may be resulting in energy inefficiency, including inadequate insulation, construction flaws, and uneven heat distribution.There are quicker and less costly measures that can be taken as well. One way to save money is to replace incandescent lights with fluorescent lights. This can result in a savings of more than 50% on your monthly lighting costs. When it's time to replace old appliances, it’s wise to spend a bit more for an energy-efficient model and be sure that you are taking advantage of energy-saving settings already on your current refrigerator, dishwasher, washing machine, or dryer.Windows provides another opportunity to cut your energy costs. Caulk old windows that might be leaky to prevent drafts and choose double-paned windows if you're building an addition or replacing old windows.Most areas of your home or apartment offer opportunities to save energy and money. The results are significant and are well worth the effort.With reference to the fourth paragraph of the passage, the meaning of the word 'Caulk' is: (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.to shut
  • B.to make more attractive
  • C.to fill the holes
  • D.to find the cause of a problem
Correct Answer: to fill the holes

In the context of the passage, "caulk" refers to sealing or filling in gaps or holes in old windows that might be leaky to prevent drafts. Therefore, option (C) is correct.

Question 48
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:Saving energy means saving money. Homeowners and renters know this basic fact, but they often don't know what kinds of adjustments they can make in their homes and apartments that will result in savings.For those willing to spend some time and money to reap long-term energy savings, an energy audit is the way to go. An energy auditor will come into your home and assess its energy efficiency. Trained energy auditors know what to look for and can locate a variety of flaws that may be resulting in energy inefficiency, including inadequate insulation, construction flaws, and uneven heat distribution.There are quicker and less costly measures that can be taken as well. One way to save money is to replace incandescent lights with fluorescent lights. This can result in a savings of more than 50% on your monthly lighting costs. When it's time to replace old appliances, it’s wise to spend a bit more for an energy-efficient model, and be sure that you are taking advantage of energy-saving settings already on your current refrigerator, dishwasher, washing machine, or dryer.Windows provide another opportunity to cut your energy costs.   • A.shouldnever be used as replacement windows or in new additions to homes.
  • B.can't be repaired
  • C.will lower your heating costs by 50%
  • D.are energy efficient

Question 49
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:Saving energy means saving money. Homeowners and renters know this basic fact, but they often don't know what kinds of adjustments they can make in their homes and apartments that will result in savings.For those willing to spend some time and money to reap long-term energy savings, an energy audit is the way to go. An energy auditor will come into your home and assess its energy efficiency. The auditor will pinpoint areas of your home that use the most energy and offer solutions to lower your energy use and costs. Trained energy auditors know what to look for and can locate a variety of flaws that may be resulting in energy inefficiency, including inadequate insulation, construction flaws, and uneven heat distribution.There are quicker and less costly measures that can be taken as well. One way to save money is to replace incandescent lights with fluorescent lights. This can result in a savings of more than 50% on your monthly lighting costs. When it's time to replace old appliances, it’s wise to spend a bit more for an energy-efficient model, and be sure that you are taking advantage of energy-saving settings already on your current refrigerator, dishwasher, washing machine, or dryer.Windows provide another opportunity to cut your energy costs. Caulk old windows that might be leaky to prevent drafts, and choose double-paned windows if you're building an addition or replacing old windows.Most areas of your home or apartment offer opportunities to save energy and money. The results are significant and are well worth the effort.According to the passage, which of the following would an energy auditor do? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)(a) Locate a variety of flaws that may result in energy inefficiency and fix them.(b) Check for construction flaws(c) Look for problems with heat distribution(d) Offer solutions to lower your energy costsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.aonly
  • B.b and c only
  • C.c and d only
  • D.b, c and d only
Correct Answer: b, c and d only

This includes locating construction flaws, identifying problems with heat distribution, and providing recommendations to reduce energy consumption, making options (b), (c), and (d) correct. Therefore, option (D) is correct.

Question 50
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below:Saving energy means saving money. Homeowners and renters know this basic fact, but they often don't know what kinds of adjustments they can make in their homes and apartments that will result in savings.For those willing to spend some time and money to reap long-term energy savings, an energy audit is the way to go. An energy auditor will come into your home and assess its energy efficiency. The auditor will pinpoint areas of your home that use the most energy and offer solutions to lower your energy use and costs. Trained energy auditors know what to look for and can locate a variety of flaws that may be resulting in energy inefficiency, including inadequate insulation, construction flaws, and uneven heat distribution.There are quicker and less costly measures that can be taken as well. One way to save money is to replace incandescent lights with fluorescent lights. This can result in a savings of more than 50% on your monthly lighting costs. When it's time to replace old appliances, it’s wise to spend a bit more for an energy-efficient model, and be sure that you are taking advantage of energy-saving settings already on your current refrigerator, dishwasher, washing machine, or dryer.Windows provide another opportunity to cut your energy costs. Caulk old windows that might be leaky to prevent drafts, and choose double-paned windows if you're building an addition or replacing old windows.Most areas of your home or apartment offer opportunities to save energy and money. The results are significant and are well worth the effort.Which of the following ideas is not included in the passage? (UGC NET Paper - 1 December 2023)
  • A.You can reduce your monthly lighting costs by more than 50% by using fluorescent bulbs instead of incandescent.
  • B.Double-paned windows can cut energy costs.
  • C.Energy audit for every home and apartment should be mandatory in India.
  • D.Some appliances have energy-saving settings
Correct Answer: Energy audit for every home and apartment should be mandatory in India.

The passage discusses various ways to save energy and money in homes and apartments, such as replacing incandescent lights with fluorescent lights, investing in energy-efficient appliances, and caulking old windows to prevent drafts. However, it does not mention anything about the mandatory requirement of energy audits for every home and apartment in India. Therefore, option (C) is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119741

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the distance travelled by a boat moving upstream (in km) during five different days of a week from Monday to Friday, along with the speed of boat (in km/hour), speed of stream (in km/hour) and total time taken (in hours). Some data is missing in the table (indicated as '-') that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Day-Wise Distance covered by a Boat and other DetailsDaysDistance Upstream(km)Speed of Boat(km/hour)Speed of Stream(km/hour)Total Time Taken(hours)Monday320-4-Tuesday---75Wednesday270-6-Thursday-117-Friday324--72Note:(A) Distance Upstream = Distance Downstream, if not stated otherwise(B) Total Time Taken = Downstream Time + Upstream TimeOn Friday, if the ratio of speed of boat to speed of stream is 2: 1, then what is the difference between the time taken by the boat to go upstream and to go downstream?
  • A.36 hours
  • B.42 hours
  • C.45 hours
  • D.35 hours
Correct Answer: 36 hours

Let speed of stream = x

Then, 3242x+x + 3242x-x = 72

or x = 6

Difference of time = 3246 - 32418 = 54 – 18 = 36 hrs

Question 2
The following table shows the distance travelled by a boat moving upstream (in km) during five different days of a week from Monday to Friday, along with the speed of boat (in km/hour), speed of stream (in km/hour) and total time taken (in hours). Some data is missing in the table (indicated as '-') that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Day-Wise Distance covered by a Boat and other DetailsDaysDistance Upstream(km)Speed of Boat(km/hour)Speed of Stream(km/hour)Total Time Taken(hours)Monday320-4-Tuesday---75Wednesday270-6-Thursday-117-Friday324--72Note:(A) Distance Upstream = Distance Downstream, if not stated otherwise(B) Total Time Taken = Downstream Time + Upstream TimeOn Monday, if the difference between the time taken by the boat to go upstream and to go downstream is 20 hours, then what is the total time taken by the boat to go upstream and downstream?
  • A.40 hours
  • B.30 hours
  • C.80 hours
  • D.60 hours
Correct Answer: 60 hours

320x-4 - 320x+4 = 20

or x = 12

Total time = 32012-4 + 32012+4 = 40 + 20 = 60 hours

Question 3
The following table shows the distance travelled by a boat moving upstream (in km) during five different days of a week from Monday to Friday, along with the speed of boat (in km/hour), speed of stream (in km/hour) and total time taken (in hours). Some data is missing in the table (indicated as '-') that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Day-Wise Distance covered by a Boat and other DetailsDaysDistance Upstream(km)Speed of Boat(km/hour)Speed of Stream(km/hour)Total Time Taken(hours)Monday320-4-Tuesday---75Wednesday270-6-Thursday-117-Friday324--72Note:(A) Distance Upstream = Distance Downstream, if not stated otherwise(B) Total Time Taken = Downstream Time + Upstream TimeOn Tuesday, if the difference between the time taken by the boat to go upstream and downstream is 45 hours and the downstream speed is 24 km/hour, then what is the total distance covered by the boat to go upstream and downstream?
  • A.680 km
  • B.720 km
  • C.740 km
  • D.540 km
Correct Answer: 720 km

Let a be the speed of boat and b be the speed of stream.

Then, xa-b + xa+b = 75 --------------(i)

and xa-b - xa+b = 45 ---------------(ii)

Solving equation (i) and (ii), we get

x = 360

Thus, total distance covered by the boat to go upstream and downstream = 360 + 360 = 720 km

Question 4
The following table shows the distance travelled by a boat moving upstream (in km) during five different days of a week from Monday to Friday, along with the speed of boat (in km/hour), speed of stream (in km/hour) and total time taken (in hours). Some data is missing in the table (indicated as '-') that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Day-Wise Distance covered by a Boat and other DetailsDaysDistance Upstream(km)Speed of Boat(km/hour)Speed of Stream(km/hour)Total Time Taken(hours)Monday320-4-Tuesday---75Wednesday270-6-Thursday-117-Friday324--72Note:(A) Distance Upstream = Distance Downstream, if not stated otherwise(B) Total Time Taken = Downstream Time + Upstream TimeOn Wednesday, if the boat covered half of the distance upstream with usual speed and other half with double its speed and it takes 3334hours less time the usual time to go upstream, then what is the total time taken by the boat to go upstream and downstream?
  • A.128 hours
  • B.120 hours
  • C.108 hours
  • D.92 hours
Correct Answer: 108 hours

135x+6 + 1352x+6 = 270x-6 - 1354

On solving, we get x = 9

Total time = 2709-6 + 2709+6 = 90 + 18 = 108 hours

Question 5
The following table shows the distance travelled by a boat moving upstream (in km) during five different days of a week from Monday to Friday, along with the speed of boat (in km/hour), speed of stream (in km/hour) and total time taken (in hours). Some data is missing in the table (indicated as '-') that you are expected to calculate, if required. Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Day-Wise Distance covered by a Boat and other DetailsDaysDistance Upstream(km)Speed of Boat(km/hour)Speed of Stream(km/hour)Total Time Taken(hours)Monday320-4-Tuesday---75Wednesday270-6-Thursday-117-Friday324--72Note:(A) Distance Upstream = Distance Downstream, if not stated otherwise(B) Total Time Taken = Downstream Time + Upstream TimeOn Thursday, the difference between the time taken by the boat to cover 'X' km upstream and (X+ 120) km downstream is 26 hours. Had the boat covered the same distance upstream as downstream, then what would have been the difference in the time taken?
  • A.58 hours
  • B.62 hours
  • C.48 hours
  • D.56 hours
Correct Answer: 56 hours

X11-7 - X+12011+7 = 26

or X = 168

 

Difference in time = 2884 - 28818 = 72 – 16 = 56 hours

Question 6
Which of the following tools can be used for virtual labs and simulations?
  • A.Plotagon
  • B.Wakelet
  • C.PhETInteractive Simulations
  • D.Flipgrid
Correct Answer: PhETInteractive Simulations

PhET Interactive Simulations is a platform that provides free interactive math and science simulations. These simulations cover various topics such as physics, chemistry, biology, earth science, and mathematics. They are designed to help students understand complex scientific concepts through interactive exploration and experimentation. PhET simulations can be used effectively for virtual labs and simulations, allowing students to conduct experiments and explore phenomena in a virtual environment.

 

Plotagon: Plotagon is a tool for creating animated videos and stories.

 

Wakelet: Wakelet is a content curation platform that allows users to save, organize, and share digital content.

 

Flipgrid: Flipgrid is a video discussion platform that allows educators and students to create and share short videos.

Question 7
Which of the following is the driving force for students' commitment, engagement and persistence in self-directed learning?
  • A.Fixation
  • B.Motivation
  • C.Metacognition
  • D.Assessment
Correct Answer: Motivation

Motivation plays a crucial role in self-directed learning as it influences students' willingness to engage in learning activities, set goals, and persist in the face of challenges. Motivated learners are more likely to actively seek out and pursue learning opportunities, take ownership of their learning process, and remain committed to achieving their learning objectives.

Note that Metacognition refers to the ability to monitor and regulate one's own thinking processes, including planning, monitoring, and evaluating learning strategies. While metacognition is important for effective self-directed learning, it is not the driving force behind students' commitment, engagement, and persistence.

Question 8
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Passive style is a way of dealing with conflict in which people are nonassertive and submissive and don't let others know what they want.Statement II:Manipulative style is a way of dealing with conflict in which people try to get what they want by making others feel guilty for them.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

Statement I: Passive style of dealing with conflict indeed involves being nonassertive and submissive, where individuals avoid expressing their own needs or desires and may acquiesce to the wishes of others to avoid conflict.

Statement II: Manipulative style of dealing with conflict involves attempting to get what one wants by using tactics such as guilt-tripping others or manipulating their emotions to gain advantage in the conflict situation.

Question 9
When students, who have learned to type on a typewriter, transfer this skill to typing on a computer keyboard, it is an example of _________ learning?
  • A.Far transfer
  • B.High-road transfer
  • C.Near transfer
  • D.Low-road transfer
Correct Answer: Near transfer

Near transfer refers to the application of skills, knowledge, or concepts learned in one situation to a similar or closely related situation. In this case, transferring the skill of typing from a typewriter to a computer keyboard involves applying the same basic skill of typing to a similar device with similar functions and layout, making it an example of near transfer.

 

Levels of Transfer Haskell's (2001) taxonomy for levels of transfer is a system of classification directly reflecting 6 precise degrees of similarity. Each level of transfer withing this taxonomy, therefore, adds greater specificity when judging the impact of connecting past learning to new situations.

 

Level 1: Nonspecific transfer - Nonspecific transfer implies that all learning essentially is transfer of learning because all learning is dependent upon being connected to past learning. This level of transfer, though true and thoroughly necessary, is perhaps unimportant in light of daily experience of transfer.

Level 2: Application transfer - Application transfer refers to the application of what we have learned to specific situations. For example, after having learned about computer programming, we are then able to genuinely apply this knowledge to actually program a computer.

Level 3: Context transfer - Context transfer, in contrast, refers to the application of what we have learned under slightly different situations. A lack of transfer may occur if the context changes, even if the learned task itself does not change. We experience this type of transfer when "place learning" plays a central role in learning because learning may be retrieved due to cues being provided by the physical place itself. For example, some of us have failed to recognize someone even though they may be staring at us.

Level 4: Near transfer - Near transfer occurs when we transfer previous knowledge to new situations closely similar to, yet not identical to, initial situations. Transferring our experiences associated with driving a car with a manual transmission to driving a truck with a manual transmission reflects an example of near procedural transfer.'

Level 5: Far transfer - Far transfer entails the application of learning to situations entirely dissimilar to the initial learning. This level of transfer of learning reflects analogical reasoning. For example, learning about logarithms in algebra and applying this knowledge in assessing the growth of bacteria in microbiology.

Level 6: Displacement or creative transfer - Displacement or creative transfer results in the creation of a new concept because of the interaction of the newly perceived similarity between the new and the old. This type of transfer of learning involves more than the mere insight that something is similar to something else. For example, the effects of the downward pull of the earth's uniform gravitational field that we experience while standing on earth is equivalent to the effects that we experience while standing in an elevator that is accelerating upwards at precisely the right rate. This transfer of learning, that acceleration and gravity is actually the same thing, refers to the Principle of Equivalence—a basic postulate of Einstein's Theory of General Relativity.

 

Significant transfer, according to Haskell (2001), requires that we learn something new in order to produce the transfer. As such, Level 4 (near transfer) and Levels 5 and 6 (far transfer) fit this category. Levels 1 and 2, however, are merely simple learning, not transfer per se. Level 3, on the other hand, is essentially the application of learning. Haskell insists that unless new learning occurs, all we have done is to merely apply the same learning rather than transfer it.

Question 10
Which factor plays a crucial role in creating an effective learning environment?
  • A.Teacher's qualification
  • B.Availability of instructional facilities
  • C.Focus on foreign language use
  • D.admission to students from elite class
Correct Answer: Availability of instructional facilities

The availability of instructional facilities, such as resources, tools, technology, and materials, is crucial in creating an effective learning environment. These facilities support teaching and learning activities, provide opportunities for hands-on experiences, enhance engagement, and facilitate the acquisition of knowledge and skills. While other factors such as teacher qualifications and student diversity can also contribute to an effective learning environment, the availability of instructional facilities forms the foundation for meaningful learning experiences.

Question 11
Identify the software that would be useful for statistical analysis of data generated in a research study:(a) SPSS(b)ithenticate(c) MINITAB(d) RChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) Only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) Only
  • C.(a), (c) and (d) Only
  • D.(a), (b) and (d) Only
Correct Answer: (a), (c) and (d) Only

iThenticate is a plagiarism-detection software that is designed to evaluate the originality of an author's work. iThenticate compares documents like journal article manuscripts, research reports, thesis, dissertations, and grant funding proposals against millions of published works, subscription databases, and the Internet.

 

SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences), also known as IBM SPSS Statistics, is a software package used for the analysis of statistical data.

 

R is a statistical computing and graphics system. This system is comprised of two parts: the R language itself (which is what most people mean when they talk about R) and a run-time environment. R is an interpreted language, which means that users access its functions through a command-line interpreter.

 

Minitab is an easy to use statistical software tools being used for data handling activities.

 

Thus, correct answer is option (C).

Question 12
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):The quantitative content analysis in social science research is a very transparent research method.Statement (II):The quantitative content analysis is often referred to as obtrusive method.In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

Option C is correct.

Statement I is true. Quantitative content analysis is transparent. While transparency is a desirable aspect of research, it's not inherently guaranteed by the method itself. Transparency depends on how well the methodology, data sources, and analytical procedures are documented and communicated.

Statement II is false. Quantitative content analysis is typically considered non-obtrusive because it involves analyzing existing texts or data without directly interfering with or altering them. Obtrusive methods typically involve direct intervention or manipulation of the research subject, which is not the case in quantitative content analysis.

Question 13
In the context of a published research article, DOI stands for:
  • A.Data Object Integration
  • B.Digital Object Identifier
  • C.Data Object Interface
  • D.Digital Object Interface
Correct Answer: Digital Object Identifier

Option B is correct.

In the context of a published research article, DOI stands for Digital Object Identifier.

Question 14
Which of the following measures would be useful for commenting upon the degree of asymmetry in a statistical distribution?
  • A.Central tendency
  • B.Dispersion
  • C.Kurtosis
  • D.Skewness
Correct Answer: Skewness

Option D is correct.

Skewness is a statistical measure that quantifies the asymmetry of a distribution. It indicates the degree to which a distribution deviates from symmetry. A distribution is symmetric if its left and right sides mirror each other. Positive skewness indicates that the distribution has a longer right tail, while negative skewness indicates a longer left tail.

Question 15
Which of the following correctly represents the meaning of the abbreviation "vide" used in academic writing?
  • A.against
  • B.width
  • C.refer to
  • D.namely
Correct Answer: refer to

In academic writing, the abbreviation "vide" is often used to indicate that the reader should refer to a specific source or reference for further information or clarification. Therefore, it means "refer to."

Question 16
A kind of fixation with medium itself is conceptualized as:
  • A.Hypermediacy
  • B.Immediacy
  • C.Media tendency
  • D.Multi-mediacy
Correct Answer: Hypermediacy

Hypermediacy refers to a fixation or emphasis on the medium itself rather than the content it conveys. It involves highlighting the characteristics and features of the medium, such as multiple layers, links, and interfaces, which may draw attention away from the message or content being communicated.

Question 17
The cyberspace is normally compared to a type of electronic:
  • A.Screen
  • B.Salon
  • C.Complex
  • D.Agora
Correct Answer: Agora

The term "Agora" refers to a gathering place or marketplace in ancient Greece, where people would come together to exchange ideas, goods, and engage in discussions. Similarly, cyberspace is often compared to an "electronic Agora" because it serves as a virtual space where people can come together, communicate, exchange information, and participate in discussions, much like the physical Agora in ancient times.

Question 18
Which of the following statements are true in respect of communication?(a) Communicated meanings are always ambiguous.(b) Words are symbols for concepts.(c) Labels may be ambiguous.(d) Symbols are usually understood within a group.(e) Sharing of meaning is not possible in communication.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) Only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) Only
  • C.(c), (d) and (e) Only
  • D.(a), (b) and (e) Only
Correct Answer: (b), (c) and (d) Only

Let us consider each given statement one by one.

 

Statement (a) is incorrect. Communicated meanings are not always ambiguous; clarity and precision in communication can often be achieved through effective encoding and decoding of messages.

Statement (b) Words are symbols for concepts: This statement is true. In communication, words serve as symbols that represent specific concepts, ideas, or objects.

Statement (c) Labels may be ambiguous: This statement is true. Labels or terms used in communication may have multiple meanings or interpretations, leading to ambiguity.

Statement (d) Symbols are usually understood within a group: This statement is true. Symbols, including language and nonverbal cues, often carry meaning that is understood within a specific cultural or social group context.

Statement (e) is also incorrect. Sharing of meaning is possible in communication when participants share a common understanding of symbols and their meanings.

 

Thus, correct answer is option B.

Question 19
Given below are two statements:Statement (I):Communication cannot reflect the cultural conduct of people.Statement (II):Communication is a practice integral to formation of social life.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I: "Communication cannot reflect the cultural conduct of people" - This statement is incorrect. Communication is deeply intertwined with culture and often reflects the cultural norms, values, beliefs, and behaviors of people. Communication practices, including language, nonverbal cues, and social norms, are shaped by culture and vary across different cultural contexts.

 

Statement II: "Communication is a practice integral to the formation of social life" - This statement is correct. Communication is fundamental to human interaction and plays a central role in the formation and maintenance of social relationships, groups, and societies. It facilitates the exchange of information, ideas, emotions, and identities, contributing to the socialization process and the construction of shared meanings and understandings among individuals and communities.

Question 20
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Communication is a social process in which people use symbols to interpret meanings in their own environment.Statement II:People and their interactions are not part of the communication process, because communication cannot be social.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I: "Communication is a social process in which people use symbols to interpret meanings in their own environment" - This statement is correct. Communication involves the exchange of messages or information using symbols (such as language) within a social context, where individuals interpret and assign meanings to these symbols based on their own environment and cultural background.

Statement II: "People and their interactions are not part of the communication process because communication cannot be social" - This statement is incorrect. Communication is inherently social, involving interactions between individuals or groups of people. It is through these interactions that communication occurs, as individuals share and interpret meanings, engage in dialogue, and influence each other's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.

Question 21
A car starts running with the initial speed of 50 km/hour, with its speed increasing every hour by 5 km per hour. How many hours will it take to cover a distance of 630 km?
  • A.7 hours
  • B.9 hours
  • C.6 hours
  • D.8 hours
Correct Answer: 9 hours

Distance travelled = 630

or 50 + 55 + 60 + ---- upto n terms = 630

or n2 [2 × 50 + (n – 1) 5] = 630

or n = 9

Thus, time taken = 9 hours.

Question 22
In a factory, the average salary of the employees is ₹ 7000. If the average salary of 12 officers is ₹ 40000 and that of the remaining employees is ₹ 6000, then the number of employees is:
  • A.402
  • B.404
  • C.406
  • D.408
Correct Answer: 408

Let total number of employees = x

Then, 12 × 40000 + (x – 12) × 6000 = 7000x

or x = 408

Thus, number of employees = 408.

Question 23
The sum of three numbers is 124. If the ratio between the first and the second is 2:3 and between the second and the third is 7:9, then the third number is:
  • A.48
  • B.54
  • C.64
  • D.66
Correct Answer: 54

The ratio between the three numbers is 14 : 21 : 27

Then, 62 x = 124

or x = 2

Third number = 27 × 2 = 54

Question 24
What will be the value of P in the following number series?0, 2, 24, 252,P, ……
  • A.3120
  • B.1029
  • C.2045
  • D.630
Correct Answer: 3120

11 – 1 = 0

22 – 2 = 2

33 – 3 = 24

44 – 4 = 252

Similarly

55 – 5 = 3120

Question 25
The cost price of an article is 75% of its marked price for sale. How much percent does the tradesman gain after allowing a discount of 15%?
  • A.20%
  • B.1313%
  • C.10%
  • D.1523%
Correct Answer: 1313%

Let MP = 100

CP = 75% of MP = 75

SP = 85

Profit% = 85-7575 × 100 = 13 13 %

Question 26
Which of the following statements are so related that they cannot both be true, nor can they both be false?(a) All mammals are vertebrates.(b) Some mammals are vertebrates.(c) Some mammals are not vertebrates.(d) No mammals are vertebrates.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (b) Only
  • B.(b) and (d) Only
  • C.(c) and (d) Only
  • D.(a) and (d) Only
Correct Answer: (b) and (d) Only

If statements cannot both be true, nor can they both be false, then they are contradictory propositions.

Question 27
Which of the following statements is logically equivalent to the statement - "All rectangles are polygon"?
  • A.Some rectangles are polygon.
  • B.No rectangles are non-polygon.
  • C.No non-rectangles are non-polygon.
  • D.All non-polygons are rectangles
Correct Answer: No rectangles are non-polygon.

Option B is obversion of given statement.

Question 28
Arrange the following terms in order of increasing intension:(a) Cheese(b) Dairy product(c) Soft Cheese(d) Strong soft cheeseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(b), (a), (c), (d)
  • B.(b), (d), (c), (a)
  • C.(d), (c), (b), (a)
  • D.(d), (c), (a), (b)
Correct Answer: (b), (a), (c), (d)

Option A is correct.

Dairy product is the most general as it encompasses a wide range of products derived from milk.

Cheese: Cheese is a subset of dairy products, so it is more specific than "dairy product" but still more general than the terms "soft cheese" and "strong soft cheese."

Soft Cheese is more specific than "cheese" but less specific than "strong soft cheese."

Strong soft cheese is the most specific as it refers to a particular type of cheese that is both soft in texture and has a strong flavor.

Question 29
"Political stability is indispensable to economic progress because economic progress can only be achieved by means of political stability" Which informal fallacy is committed in the above statement?
  • A.Slippery Slope
  • B.Red Herring
  • C.HastyGeneralisation
  • D.Begging the question
Correct Answer: Begging the question

Begging the question, also known as circular reasoning, occurs when the conclusion of an argument is assumed within one of its premises. In this statement, the speaker assumes the truth of the conclusion—"Political stability is indispensable to economic progress"—within the premise, "economic progress can only be achieved by means of political stability."

The argument is circular because it presupposes the truth of the conclusion within one of its premises without providing independent evidence or support. It assumes that political stability is necessary for economic progress, which is the very conclusion being argued for.

Question 30
Given below are two statements:Statement I:The proposition "The hill has fire because it is knowable" commits the fallacy of the irregular middle.Statement II:The proposition "Sound is eternal, because it is audible" commits the fallacy of the irregular middle.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Savyabhichära or Anaikäntika: This is the fallacy of the irregular middle. It is of three kinds:-

(a) Sädharana: Here the middle term is too wide. It is present in both the sapaksa (positive) and the vipaksa (negative) instances and violates the rule that the middle should not be present in the negative instances (vipaksäsattva); e.g., ‘the hill has fire because it is knowable’. Here ‘knowable is present in fiery as well as non-fiery objects.

(b) Asädhärana: Here the middle term is too narrow. It is present only in the paksa and neither in the sapaksa nor in the vipaksa. It violates the rule that the middle term should be present in the sapaksa (sapaksasattva); e.g., ‘sound is eternal, because it is audible. Here audibility belongs to sound only and is present nowhere else.

(c) Anupasamhäri : Here the middle term is non-exclusive. The minor term is all-inclusive and leaves nothing by way of sapaksa or vipaksa; e.g., 'all things are non-eternal, because they are knowable.

Question 31
Given below are two statements:Statement I: Google is a web search engine, whilegooglechrome is a web browser.Statement II:Microsoft Edge is a web search engine, while Microsoft Bing is a web browser.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.

Statement I: "Google is a web search engine, while Google Chrome is a web browser" - This statement is correct. Google is a web search engine, providing users with the ability to search for information on the internet, while Google Chrome is a web browser, allowing users to access and navigate websites on the internet.

Statement II: "Microsoft Edge is a web search engine, while Microsoft Bing is a web browser" - This statement is incorrect. Microsoft Edge is a web browser developed by Microsoft, while Bing is a web search engine also developed by Microsoft. Therefore, the roles of the products in Statement II are reversed, making the statement incorrect.

Question 32
Consider the following memory hierarchy diagram:Which of the following memories A-D representsI, II, III and IV (in that order)?(a) Magnetic Tape(b) Magnetic Hard Disk(c) Random Access Memory(d) Processor RegistersChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(d), (c), (a), (b)
  • B.(a), (b), (c), (d)
  • C.(b), (c), (d), (a)
  • D.(d), (c), (b), (a)
Correct Answer: (d), (c), (b), (a)

Option D is correct.

Processor Registers represents the fastest and smallest type of memory directly accessible by the CPU.

Random Access Memory (RAM) is the main memory used by the computer for storing data that is actively being used.

Magnetic Hard Disk is a secondary storage device used for long-term storage of data.

Magnetic Tape is a sequential storage medium often used for backup and archival purposes due to its relatively slow access times compared to other storage devices.

Question 33
Match List -1 with List - II.List - I (ICT Term)(a) Firewall(b) Digital certificate(c) Cookies(d) HypervisorList - II (Definition)(I) Used to remember user's preferences each time they visit websites(II) Hardware or software that sits between a user's computer and an external network, which filters data coming to and from the computer(III) Software, firmware or hardware that creates and runs a virtual machine(IV) Pairs of files stored on user's computer; each pair contains a public key and private keyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)

Option C is correct.

Firewall - Hardware or software that sits between a user's computer and an external network, which filters data coming to and from the computer. Firewalls are used to protect networks from unauthorized access and malicious activities.

Digital certificate - Pairs of files stored on the user's computer; each pair contains a public key and private key. Digital certificates are used in public key infrastructure (PKI) to verify the authenticity of entities, such as websites or individuals, and to facilitate secure communication over the internet.

Cookies - Used to remember user's preferences each time they visit websites. Cookies are small pieces of data stored on the user's computer by websites to track user activity and preferences.

Hypervisor - Software, firmware, or hardware that creates and runs a virtual machine. Hypervisors are used to manage and allocate resources to virtual machines, allowing multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine.

Question 34
Consider the followingMs-Excel work sheet:ABC1MonthNumber of classes taughtPayments (in ₹) made @ 1500 per class2January20300003February14210004March17255005April13195006May12180007June1522500The value returned by the function:=SUMIFS (C2 : C7, B2 : B7, ">13", C2 : C7, ">22500") is :
  • A.78000
  • B.76500
  • C.99000
  • D.55500
Correct Answer: 55500

Required value = 30000 + 25500 = 55500

Question 35
Given below are two statements with refers to the different number systems:Statement I:(0.6875)10=(0.1011)2Statement II:(111011.101)2=(58.625)10In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

(0.1011)2 = 1 × 2-1 + 0 × 2-2 + 1 × 2-3 + 1 × 2-4

= 0.5 + 0.250 + 0.125 + 0.0625

= 0.6875

 

(111011.101)2 = 1 × 20 + 1 × 21 + 0 × 22 + 1 × 23 + 1 × 24 + 1 × 25 + 1 × 2-1 + 0 × 2-2 + 1 × 2-3 = 1 + 2 + 8 + 16 + 32 + 0.5 + 0.125

= 59.625

 

So, statement I is correct while statement II is incorrect.

Question 36
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Photovoltaic cells produce Alternating current (a.c.).Statement II:Photovoltaic cells are exposed directly to the sun, therefore as temperature rises leakage across the cell increases.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Option D is correct.

Statement I is incorrect. Photovoltaic cells produce direct current (d.c.) when exposed to sunlight, not alternating current (a.c.). The process of converting sunlight into electricity through photovoltaic cells generates direct current.

Statement II is correct. Photovoltaic cells are directly exposed to sunlight to generate electricity. However, as the temperature rises, the efficiency of photovoltaic cells can decrease, and there can be an increase in leakage currents across the cell. Higher temperatures can lead to an increase in resistance within the cell, which can result in higher leakage currents and reduced efficiency.

Question 37
Which of the following pairs of elements is most important for eutrophication process?
  • A.Calcium-magnesium
  • B.Nitrogen-phosphorus
  • C.Nickel-cobalt
  • D.Iron-copper
Correct Answer: Nitrogen-phosphorus

Option B is correct.

Eutrophication is a process where a body of water becomes overly enriched with nutrients, leading to excessive growth of algae and other aquatic plants. Among the nutrients involved in eutrophication, nitrogen and phosphorus are considered the most important factors.

Question 38
The standard coagulant in water treatment is?
  • A.Hypochloride
  • B.Chlorine
  • C.Aluminum
  • D.Alum
Correct Answer: Alum

Option D is correct.

Alum, or aluminum sulfate, is the standard coagulant commonly used in water treatment processes because of the following reasons:

Coagulation is a crucial step in water treatment where particles in the water, including suspended solids, colloids, and microorganisms, are destabilized and brought together to form larger aggregates or flocs. These flocs can then be more easily removed through sedimentation and filtration.

Alum is one of the most widely used coagulants in water treatment. When added to water, alum dissociates into aluminum ions (Al^3+) and sulfate ions (SO4^2-). The aluminum ions neutralize the negative charges on the particles in the water, allowing them to come together and form flocs.

Alum is effective at removing a wide range of impurities from water, including suspended solids, organic matter, and certain dissolved substances. It helps improve the clarity and quality of water.

Alum is readily available, relatively inexpensive, and easy to handle, making it a practical choice for water treatment facilities, particularly in areas where other coagulants may be less accessible or more costly.

Question 39
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as Assertion ‘A’ and the other is labelled as Reason ‘R’.Assertion ‘A’:PM10is preferred over Total Suspended Particles (TSP) for air quality monitoring studies.Reason ‘R’:Particles larger than 10 micron are better indicator of potential health effects of particulate air pollution.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct and ‘R’ is the correct explanation of ‘A’
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct but ‘R’ is not the correct explanation of ‘A’
  • C.‘A’ is correct but ‘R’ is not correct
  • D.‘A’ is not correct but ‘R’ is correct
Correct Answer: ‘A’ is correct but ‘R’ is not correct

Option C is correct.

  • Assertion is correct. PM10 (particulate matter with a diameter of 10 micrometers or less) is preferred over Total Suspended Particles (TSP) for air quality monitoring studies. PM10 specifically targets particles that are smaller than 10 micrometers in diameter, which are known to penetrate deep into the respiratory system and pose significant health risks. Therefore, PM10 is considered a more relevant indicator for assessing potential health impacts of particulate air pollution compared to TSP.

Reason is not correct. While particles smaller than 10 micrometers (PM10) are associated with adverse health effects, it is not accurate to state that particles larger than 10 micrometers are a better indicator of potential health effects. In fact, particles smaller than 10 micrometers, particularly those smaller than 2.5 micrometers (PM2.5), are often considered even more harmful to human health as they can penetrate deeper into the lungs and even enter the bloodstream.

Question 40
Given below are two statements:Statement I:The Richter Scale measures not only the intensity of earthquake itself, but its impact on people too.Statement II:The modifiedMercalliscale measures the earthquake in terms of energy released.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect

Option B is correct.

Statement I is incorrect. The Richter Scale is a logarithmic scale that measures the amplitude of seismic waves produced by an earthquake. It quantifies the size or magnitude of an earthquake, but it does not directly measure the impact of the earthquake on people or structures. The Richter Scale does not account for factors such as distance from the epicenter or local geological conditions, which can significantly influence the impact of an earthquake.

Statement II is also incorrect. The modified Mercalli scale, also known as the Mercalli Intensity Scale, measures the intensity of an earthquake based on its observed effects on people, buildings, and the natural environment. It does not measure the energy released by the earthquake, as it focuses on the earthquake's effects rather than its underlying physical properties.

Question 41
Which of the following Open universities was established in accordance with the National Education policy, 1986:
  • A.Dr. B.R Ambedkar Open University, Hyderabad
  • B.Indira Gandhi National Open University, Delhi
  • C.Karnataka State Open University, Mysore
  • D.YashwantRaoChavanMaharashtra open University, Nasik
Correct Answer: Indira Gandhi National Open University, Delhi

The establishment of the Indira Gandhi National Open University aligns with the goals outlined in the National Education Policy, 1986. The policy aimed to expand opportunities for higher education, ensuring accessibility, cost-effectiveness, and promoting a flexible and innovative education system. Indira Gandhi National Open University was founded in September 1985 with these objectives in mind. The university has been entrusted with the responsibility of coordinating the distance learning system in the country and setting standards for it.

Question 42
Which of the following universities in ancient India had six colleges each under them and had a lot of exchange of ideas between them?(a)Sridhanyakatak(b)Nalanda(c)Takshashila(d)VikramashilaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a) and (b) Only
  • B.(b) and (d) Only
  • C.(c) and (d) Only
  • D.(a) and (d) Only
Correct Answer: (b) and (d) Only

Both Nalanda and Vikramashila universities in ancient India had six colleges each under them and had a lot of exchange of ideas between them.

Question 43
Find out the correct chronological order of the establishment of following universities in India:(a) Agra University(b) Delhi University(c) Nagpur University(d) Andhra University(e) University of CalcuttaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(b), (c), (a), (e), (d)
  • B.(e), (b), (c), (d), (a)
  • C.(c), (d), (a), (e), (b)
  • D.(a), (e), (b), (d), (c)
Correct Answer: (e), (b), (c), (d), (a)

The correct chronological order of the establishment of given universities in India is as follows.

(i) University of Calcutta - 1857

(ii) Delhi University - 1922

(iii) Nagpur University - 1923

(iv) Andhra University - 1926

(v) Agra University – 1927

Therefore, option B is correct.

Question 44
Match List - IwithList - II.List - I (Commission/Committee)(a) Sadler Commission(b)HartogCommittee(c)RadhakrishnanCommission(d)YashpalCommitteeList - II (Focus area)(i) Functioning of UGC and AICTE(ii) University education in India(iii) Comprehensive report on education in India(iv) Functioning of Calcutta universityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)

The correct match is as follows.

List - I - List - II

(Commission/Committee) - (Focus area)

(a) Sadler Commission - Functioning of Calcutta university

The Sadler Commission was a commission set up to inquire into the conditions and prospects of the University of Calcutta.

 

(b) Hartog Committee - Comprehensive report on education in India

The British government in 1929 appointed the Sir Philip Joseph Hartog committee to survey on the growth of education in India.

 

(c) Radhakrishnan Commission - University education in India

The Radha Krishna Commission was established to review the current state of university education in India and make recommendations for improvement.

 

(d) Yashpal Committee - Functioning of UGC and AICTE

The committee proposed doing away with regulatory bodies like UGC and AICTE. Instead, it recommended establishing independent bodies for higher education regulation.

Question 45
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Financing higher education in a country like India depends upon availability of resources and other financial implications.Statement II:According to NEP 2020, funding and financing of higher education will be carried out by the second vertical of Higher Education Commission of India i.e., Higher Education Grants Council.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Statement (I): Financing higher education in a country like India depend on the availability of resources and other financial implications. This statement is true.

 

Statement (II): The third vertical of HECI will be the Higher Education Grants Council (HEGC), which will carry out funding and financing of higher education based on transparent criteria.

 

Higher Education Commission of India (HECI) will be set up as a single umbrella body for the entire higher education, excluding medical and legal education. Public and private higher education institutions will be governed by the same set of norms for regulation, accreditation and academic standards. Also, HECI will be having 4 independent verticals namely,

1. National Higher Education Regulatory Council (NHERC) for regulation,

2. General Education Council (GEC) for standard setting,

3. Higher Education Grants Council (HEGC) for funding,

4. National Accreditation Council (NAC) for accreditation.

 

Thus, statement (II) is incorrect as HEGC is third vertical of HECI but not second vertical as mentioned in the statement.

Question 46
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Tiger reserves are an important part of our tourism industry. There are 42 declared tiger reserves in India which are generally operated by state forest departments. Indian tiger, also known as Bengal tiger is the national animal of India. Its scientific name is Pantherstigristigris. Tigers are maintained in reserves for their scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values and they are kept as national heritage for the education and enjoyment of the people.But in recent years tiger tourism has become a troublesome issue due to the rapid growth of killing of tigers due to illegal poaching. This is a wakeup call not only for the department of tourism but also for the various wildlifeorganisationsand other governing bodies. Since the governments have failed to implement adequate enforcement response and investigations, wildlife crimes have increased by years. Today there are some activists and environmentalists who are demanding a complete ban on public access to wildlife reserves. But such a complete ban would be a setback.There is no question that commercial tourism must be strictly regulated, however a complete ban would be an extremely harmful step, as it will negatively impact conservation education, monitoring and other conservation activities.Tiger tourism has become a problem in recent years because:
  • A.There are too many tigers
  • B.Tigers kill people
  • C.Tourists disturb tigers
  • D.There is illegal poaching of tigers
Correct Answer: There is illegal poaching of tigers

The passage states that tiger tourism has become a troublesome issue due to the rapid growth of killing of tigers due to illegal poaching. This illegal poaching poses a significant threat to the tiger population and undermines conservation efforts. Therefore, option (D) is the correct answer.

Question 47
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Tiger reserves are an important part of our tourism industry. There are 42 declared tiger reserves in India which are generally operated by state forest departments. Indian tiger, also known as Bengal tiger is the national animal of India. Its scientific name is Pantherstigristigris. Tigers are maintained in reserves for their scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values and they are kept as national heritage for the education and enjoyment of the people.But in recent years tiger tourism has become a troublesome issue due to the rapid growth of killing of tigers due to illegal poaching. This is a wakeup call not only for the department of tourism but also for the various wildlifeorganisationsand other governing bodies. Since the governments have failed to implement adequate enforcement response and investigations, wildlife crimes have increased by years. Today there are some activists and environmentalists who are demanding a complete ban on public access to wildlife reserves. But such a complete ban would be a setback.There is no question that commercial tourism must be strictly regulated, however a complete ban would be an extremely harmful step, as it will negatively impact conservation education, monitoring and other conservation activities.Solution to the problem of wild life crimes can be found by:
  • A.Banning public access to wildlife reserves
  • B.Banning tiger tourism
  • C.Regulating commercial tourism
  • D.Curtailment of wild life population
Correct Answer: Regulating commercial tourism

The passage suggests that while a complete ban on public access to wildlife reserves, as advocated by some activists, may seem like a solution, it would be a setback. Instead, the passage argues that commercial tourism must be strictly regulated. Therefore, option (C) is the most appropriate answer.

Question 48
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Tiger reserves are an important part of our tourism industry. There are 42 declared tiger reserves in India which are generally operated by state forest departments. Indian tiger, also known as Bengal tiger is the national animal of India. Its scientific name is Pantherstigristigris. Tigers are maintained in reserves for their scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values and they are kept as national heritage for the education and enjoyment of the people.But in recent years tiger tourism has become a troublesome issue due to the rapid growth of killing of tigers due to illegal poaching. This is a wakeup call not only for the department of tourism but also for the various wildlifeorganisationsand other governing bodies. Since the governments have failed to implement adequate enforcement response and investigations, wildlife crimes have increased by years. Today there are some activists and environmentalists who are demanding a complete ban on public access to wildlife reserves. But such a complete ban would be a setback.There is no question that commercial tourism must be strictly regulated, however a complete ban would be an extremely harmful step, as it will negatively impact conservation education, monitoring and other conservation activities.A protected area for animals, plants etc. is called:
  • A.A Reserve
  • B.A Forest
  • C.Countryside
  • D.Cantonment
Correct Answer: A Reserve

A protected area for animals, plants, etc., is commonly referred to as a reserve. In the context of the passage, tiger reserves are specifically mentioned as important areas for the conservation of tigers and their habitats. Therefore, option (A) is the most appropriate choice.

Question 49
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Tiger reserves are an important part of our tourism industry. There are 42 declared tiger reserves in India which are generally operated by state forest departments. Indian tiger, also known as Bengal tiger is the national animal of India. Its scientific name is Pantherstigristigris. Tigers are maintained in reserves for their scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values and they are kept as national heritage for the education and enjoyment of the people.But in recent years tiger tourism has become a troublesome issue due to the rapid growth of killing of tigers due to illegal poaching. This is a wakeup call not only for the department of tourism but also for the various wildlifeorganisationsand other governing bodies. Since the governments have failed to implement adequate enforcement response and investigations, wildlife crimes have increased by years. Today there are some activists and environmentalists who are demanding a complete ban on public access to wildlife reserves. But such a complete ban would be a setback.There is no question that commercial tourism must be strictly regulated, however a complete ban would be an extremely harmful step, as it will negatively impact conservation education, monitoring and other conservation activities.Tigers are kept in reserves for the following reasons:(a) Ecological value(b) Cultural value(c) Agricultural value(d) Aesthetic value(e) Medicinal valueChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a), (b) and (d) Only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) Only
  • C.(c), (d) and (e) Only
  • D.(a), (d) and (e) Only
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (d) Only

In the passage, it is mentioned that tigers are maintained in reserves for their scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural, and ecological values. Specifically, the passage highlights their ecological, cultural, and aesthetic values. Therefore, the correct options are (a), (b), and (d), which represent ecological value, cultural value, and aesthetic value respectively.

Question 50
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow:Tiger reserves are an important part of our tourism industry. There are 42 declared tiger reserves in India which are generally operated by state forest departments. Indian tiger, also known as Bengal tiger is the national animal of India. Its scientific name is Pantherstigristigris. Tigers are maintained in reserves for their scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values and they are kept as national heritage for the education and enjoyment of the people.But in recent years tiger tourism has become a troublesome issue due to the rapid growth of killing of tigers due to illegal poaching. This is a wakeup call not only for the department of tourism but also for the various wildlifeorganisationsand other governing bodies. Since the governments have failed to implement adequate enforcement response and investigations, wildlife crimes have increased by years. Today there are some activists and environmentalists who are demanding a complete ban on public access to wildlife reserves. But such a complete ban would be a setback.There is no question that commercial tourism must be strictly regulated, however a complete ban would be an extremely harmful step, as it will negatively impact conservation education, monitoring and other conservation activities.Given below are two statements:Statement I:Banning commercial tourism will positively impact conservation activities.Statement II:Pantheratigristigrisis the national animal of India.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both StatementIand Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

Statement I: Banning commercial tourism will not necessarily positively impact conservation activities, as indicated in the passage. While commercial tourism must be strictly regulated, a complete ban could have negative consequences for conservation education, monitoring, and other conservation activities. Therefore Statement is incorrect.

 

Statement II: Panthera tigris tigris is the scientific name for the Indian tiger, which is also known as the Bengal tiger and is the national animal of India. Therefore, Statement II is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119742

Total Questions: 50
Question 1
The following table shows the percentage of marks obtained by six different students in six different subjects A-F of MCA programme in a University, along with the maximum marks in each subject (shown in brackets). Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Student-wise Percentage of Marks in Six SubjectsStudentsSubjects (Maximum Marks)A (150)B (100)C (150)D (125)E (75)F (50)Anil66%75%88%56%56%90%Arman82%76%84%96%92%88%Arpit76%66%78%88%72%70%Gaurav90%88%96%76%84%86%Gurjit64%70%68%72%68%74%Priya48%56%50%64%64%58%How many marks did Anil get in all the six subjects together?
  • A.369
  • B.463
  • C.558
  • D.496
Correct Answer: 463

Total marks of Anil = 66% of 150 + 75% of 100 + 88% of 150 + 56% of 125 + 56% of 75 + 90% of 50 = 463

Question 2
The following table shows the percentage of marks obtained by six different students in six different subjects A-F of MCA programme in a University, along with the maximum marks in each subject (shown in brackets).   • B.three
  • C.four
  • D.five

Question 3
The following table shows the percentage of marks obtained by six different students in six different subjects A-F of MCA programme in a University, along with the maximum marks in each subject (shown in brackets). Question 4

Question 5
The following table shows the percentage of marks obtained by six different students in six different subjects A-F of MCA programme in a University, along with the maximum marks in each subject (shown in brackets). Based on the data in the table, answer the questions that follow.Student-wise Percentage of Marks in Six SubjectsStudentsSubjects (Maximum Marks)A (150)B (100)C (150)D (125)E (75)F (50)Anil66%75%88%56%56%90%Arman82%76%84%96%92%88%Arpit76%66%78%88%72%70%Gaurav90%88%96%76%84%86%Gurjit64%70%68%72%68%74%Priya48%56%50%64%64%58%What is the difference between the average marks obtained in subjects A and E by all the six students together?
